title: My boyfriend and I found an abandoned house. We turned the gas & electric on in our name and have been occupying it for the last 9mo. Then property managemnt comes and locks us out with no notice. Is that legal? - Quora
tags: Legal Issues and Law in Everyday Life

response.answer_text: As others have pointed out generally as a squatter (at least in the US) you have very little rights. There is the concept of adverse possession: State-by-State Rules on Adverse Possession but that’s generally measured in years and almost certainly not going to apply in your case. That said, some cities are starting to recognize a lesser form, especially if it helps fight urban blight. You have a couple of choices here: Move. This is 100% legal. Consider yourselves lucky for getting housing that only cost the price of gas and electric for 9 months. Many would be so luckly.Find a local legal aid society. Some cities have tenants rights groups that may be able to point you in the right direction and even provide legal counsel. That said, most likely you end up back at choice #1.The least likely to work, but honestly, if it does, in some ways the best outcome for all: Throw yourself on the mercy of the property owners. Now, they almost certainly will say, “get lost” for a number of reasons, many attached to liability (let’s say you had gotten injured while on the property and had immense legal bills. You’re responsible, so if you hired a lawyer they might suggest going after the landowner, etc.) Also, you’ve already shown a breach of faith by basically ‘stealing’ from them. That said, you can also argue that you kept the property from decaying (if it was abandoned, my guess there was no upkeep being done) and helped keep their value up. You can also appeal to their humanity. And, most of all, be willing to pay rent going forward (and perhaps back rent).I think the 3rd outcome is the least likely (though it might be possible of choice 2 is followed) but, honestly, might be the most equitable. They get tenants paying rent in an otherwise abandoned property and you get a roof over your head. Good luck.

It sure is. First of all, just because a house is empty, doesn't mean it's abandoned. Second of all, you're a jerk for attempting to steal someone's property from them. How do you know that the owner isn't military and away on a multi-year duty assignment? They definitely still pay the taxes…Ye ah, you don't…jerk. Nextly, just because you turned on utilities, doesn't mean you have some kind of legal right to continue being there (think of it like illegal immigrants…just because they're here, doesn't mean they're legally welcome to stay as long as they want without penalty). Lastly, you were trespassing. Had you actually done some kind of research, you MIGHT have found that the house was owned by someone and not truly abandoned.

This very thing just happened to me. After a long while out of town, I came to move into my condo. In my absence, a friend of mine has cleaned up after bad tenants. I am expecting to pit my key in the door and walk into a move-in ready condo. Nope, I find 17 squatters. They have changed the locks and turned on the utilities in their own name. They tell me to kick rocks, they’ve been here for months, they believe they have rights. I call the police. The police tell them, you have 30 minutes to collect your possessions and leave, or we will forcibly enter, and you will all go to jail for trespass and vandalism. Not huge charges, I know. But basically, be glad you got locked out and not locked up. The nerve.

So, you are saying you entered a house you do not own , squatted there, and when the rightful owner comes by eventually and instead of calling the police and saying that there are vagrants, trespassers and/or homelesd squatters on his property, he locks you out of his house. You are questioning the legality of such? Okay, what you and your boyfriend performed is also called Adverse Possession. Usually, for you to be able to claim the property you would have to haf stay the for a set amount of time. Since you did not inform us of what state this occurred. So, any information I give you would be wrong. Instead, I will provide you a link so you may research it properly.State-by-State Rules on Adverse Possession

You were trespassing which is illegal you had no right to be in the house in the first place under the law you could check with a real lawyer. The property manager had every right to bar you from the house if he’s acting on behalf of the legal owner. You used an address that was not legally yours to obtain gas and electricity whether or not the utilities will come after you for fraud is uncertain. Being homeless is terrible I hope you can find a place to live that is legally yours until then I am not a lawyer and I don’t know where you live very few places protect or encourage squatting. Maybe in Australia they have different laws or other jurisdictions I’m not aware of.

If there is a management company involved, you did not find an “abandoned house" you found a property between renters,and committed a felony in most states called breaking and entering. People that “abandon" a house don't spend the not insubstantial amount of money a property management company costs. What you did is absolutely a crime. You have deprived a legal owner the use and income of their property, if it were me I would see to it you and your boyfriend were prosecuted to the fullest extent the law allows.

How you got there doesn’t matter. Ethical or not. Depending on where you’re located, I don’t believe it’s legal. It’s not in most states. Since you’ve lived there for over 30 days and have proof (your electric and gas bill) the management company cannot just lock you out/throw your things away, etc. The fact that it took 9 months for them to take action is also in your favor. They need to go through a proper eviction procedure. Contact your local police department.

Squatters rights vary from state to state so you’d need to investigate local state law. Usually if you never lived there and have no right to the property and it’s residential then they can do what they like. Sometimes people can squat long enough and if gone unnoticed can claim the property. How ever this takes years, a decade or more and as I said laws vary state to state. In short though yes then can lock you out.

No. They must evict. In some states you can break the lock or call police and have them do it. While you shouldn't have just moved in, after a month there you gained rights as a resident. Contact the mgmt property and demand a key pointing out it's illegal to lock you out without eviction order. If they refuse contact the police. If you're state requires it they'll have to you goto court that day or next and get an order so they can break the door if needed.

You belong in prison, where you also get free housing, and food, clothing and medical care. What you did is theft. The property isn't yours, and you have NO right to live there. It would be like driving someone else's car for a week because it was just sitting there in their driveway, and expecting to be given a pass by the cops because you put gas in it while you were driving your stolen car.

As squatters you have rights. To get you out they must evict you legally. Go to the police and file a complaint.show them the gaz and electric bill in your name. They will force the management company to let you in. If they file for eviction go to court with the copy of the complaint. Show the judge they illegally evicted you. Alternatively you might negotiate with them for a lump sum to move out because they will get fined for the illegal eviction.

Considering that you were illegally occupying a house that you do not own, do not pay property taxes on, did not have permission to be there, of course the proper owners and/or managers have the legal right to kick you out. What is wrong with you? How can you possibly think that the legal owner and/or manager of the property would not have the right to expel you for living there? Are you nuts?

You “found” it? Like down the back of a really large sofa? Floating around at sea? What you found wasn't lost. You got 9 months free off it. Move on, use the small fortune you saved (were you paying utilities, or did you just turn them back on?)

You are effectively called “squatters” - that is if, you did not make any attempt at all to find out if you can legally take over and live in this abandoned home. Now, the owners or its representative finally came and took back what belong to them…. And that is legal. It’s their property not yours.

by law No it is illegal. you lucky if you commit crime and police find out you are living in abandoned house then you end up in jail. if you living in abandoned house it belong to government.if police get involved you end in jail.
Yes. You were trespassing. If there’s a property management company,managing the property,it’s not “abandoned”,it's just vacant.
What you should be asking is if what you and your boyfriend did was legal, which it was not. You are called ‘squatters’. You had no permission to live there.
Yes - locking you out was legal since you had NO LEGAL RIGHT to be on the property. People don’t need to give notice when they take back “stolen” property.
Apparently it was not abandoned and even if it was you were trespassing. Yes it is legal to throw out someone who was not legally supposed to be there.
